channel.title: development on Kris Hicks
channel.description: Recent content in development on Kris Hicks

item.title: There is Always a Better Way
item.description:
I got into software development because of a single idea: there is always a better way.

I was working at a title insurance company in the US during the housing boom of 2007. I was hired as a temp to do data entry for the calculation of fees associated with purchasing title insurance. It was a straightforward job, with one incredible hindrance: everyone was using adding machines, which is a fancy desktop calculator that prints out a receipt as you enter calculations.

item.title: Using gRPC with Mutual TLS in Golang
item.description: So, you want to use gRPC. Cool! And you want to use mutual TLS, too. But maybe, like me, you couldn't easily figure out how to accomplish this, given the documentation and examples out there. Here's how I did it.

item.title: Using git subtree with gh-pages
item.description: I recently switched to using Hugo to generate this site and needed a strategy to publish it. Previously I was using Octopress which has scripts for managing the gh-pages branch automatically. The documentation on gohugo.io shows a workflow that uses git subtree, a tool I knew about but had never actually used before. I found the tutorial on the gohugo.io page to be confusing. Here, I describe the approach I used instead.

item.title: How to set up a Clojure dev environment on Snow Leopard
item.description:
Homebrew (package manager)

$ ruby -e "$(curl -fsSkL raw.github.com/mxcl/homebrew/go)"

More information on Homebrew can be found on the Homebrew home page

item.title: rewinding git pull
item.description: If you're using a rebase strategy for the first time you may run git pull in a situation where Git practically tells you to do it, but you don't actually want to do it.

item.title: git quick tips
item.description: The following are things I found very helpful, which you also may find make your day-to-day usage of Git more enjoyable.

item.title: rewinding git commit --amend
item.description: It may come to pass that you will run git commit --amend by mistake. When this happens, you'll want to unwind the operation you just did.

item.title: rerere
item.description:
There have been times where I performed a rebase and had to resolve conflicts as part of the rebase, and then decided to abort the rebase for one reason or another.

Without rerere the next time I went to perform the rebase I'd end up having to resolve at least some of the same conflicts I had previously, which is annoying.

This is where rerere comes in.

item.title: git rebase --onto
item.description: Have you ever dug into the git rebase documentation and noticed there's a three-argument form of it?

item.title: git add -e
item.description: git add -e is like git add -p, except instead of adding things at the hunk level, you edit the entire patch at once.

item.title: git reset -p
item.description: I've been using git reset -p a lot recently and I think it makes sense to clarify what it is that it does because when I first started using it I found it a little confusing.

item.title: git exec
item.description:
(Update #1 below)

Say you're going to do an interactive rebase where you're going to be squashing commits or reordering them. During this process you may want Git to execute a command after applying certain items of the todo list. An example of this would be when you want to run rake or similar to ensure a newly-squashed commit is still green.
